content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

I see multiple tissue sections on the slide. At least five of these are ovoid and densely cellular (dark purple), consistent with lymph nodes of varying sizes. Several of the larger nodes appear almost entirely replaced by these purple cells, which is highly suspicious for extensive metastatic disease. There are also smaller fragments of tissue, and some inking (blue/green and black) is present for orientation.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into this area because it represents the first lymph node in a systematic review of the slide, starting from the top left. The primary task is to identify any positive lymph nodes for cancer staging. Therefore, every single lymph node, regardless of its size, must be carefully examined at high power to look for metastatic tumor cells. This particular node is small, but it could still harbor a micrometastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. When staging colorectal cancer, it is crucial to examine all submitted tissue for evidence of lymph node metastasis. The area highlighted by the green box is within a piece of tissue that is predominantly fibro-adipose (fatty and fibrous). However, there is a small, distinct focus of purple cells that stands out against the pale background. Any such cellular aggregate must be investigated at high magnification to determine its nature. It could be a very small, benign lymph node, a reactive lymphoid aggregate, or, most importantly, a small metastatic deposit or a completely replaced lymph node. Thorough examination of these small foci is essential for accurate N (nodal) staging. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this specific area because, at low magnification, it contains a small, subtle, and isolated basophilic (purple) focus within a larger piece of fibrofatty tissue, separate from the more obvious lymph nodes. Such small foci are critical to identify and characterize for accurate staging. This could represent a very small lymph node, a tumor deposit (TD), or lymphovascular invasion (LVI). Careful high-power examination is required to distinguish between these possibilities, which have different implications for the patient's pN stage and prognosis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my task is to screen every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. I am systematically examining each node on the slide. This particular node, one of the largest, is a high-priority target for inspection. The area I am zooming into is at the edge of the main lymphoid aggregate. This region, particularly the subcapsular sinus area, is a common site for the initial deposition of metastatic tumor cells. The subtle textural variation seen at low power in this area also makes it a region of interest. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist staging a colorectal cancer case, I must meticulously examine every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The green box highlights one of these lymph nodes, specifically the one in the bottom right corner. I am zooming into this area to assess its internal architecture and the interface with the surrounding fat tissue at high magnification. My goal is to look for atypical epithelial cells (metastatic carcinoma) within the lymphoid tissue and to check for extranodal extension (tumor cells breaching the lymph node capsule and invading the surrounding fat). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area, which is the second lymph node from the top left, because it exhibits the suspicious features I noted at low power. There is a distinct, non-homogenous, paler area within the otherwise dark lymphoid tissue. This suggests a focal lesion, and given the context of colorectal cancer, it is highly likely to be a metastatic tumor deposit. A high-power examination is necessary to confirm the presence of atypical glandular cells and make a definitive diagnosis of a positive lymph node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine each lymph node on the slide. The zoom is directed at the lymph node located in the bottom right corner. This node is visibly cellular and appears to have an abnormal architecture even at low power. The specific area of the zoom is at the periphery of the main cellular mass, which is a good location to evaluate the interface between native lymphoid tissue and potential tumor deposits. Zooming in is essential to assess the cytology of the cells and the tissue architecture to confirm or rule out the presence of metastatic carcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining each lymph node to look for evidence of metastasis. This particular lymph node, located on the bottom right, appears cellular and requires high-power examination to assess its architecture. I need to check the subcapsular sinus and the parenchyma for the presence of atypical epithelial cells, which would indicate a positive node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see a dense, monotonous population of small, round, darkly stained cells, which are characteristic of lymphocytes. The overall architecture of the lymph node appears preserved, with a fibrous capsule visible at the bottom right. I do not see any atypical glandular structures, clusters of epithelial cells with large pleomorphic nuclei, or significant necrosis that would indicate metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis. I would proceed to examine the rest of this node and all other nodes on the slide.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in image shows a small, well-circumscribed aggregate of lymphocytes. These cells are small, round, and have dark nuclei, which is typical for benign lymphocytes. This aggregate is located within mature adipose tissue (the large white circular spaces) and fibrous connective tissue (pink wavy material). There are no atypical cells, no glandular formation, and no large pleomorphic nuclei to suggest the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a very small, benign lymph node or a reactive lymphoid aggregate. It is negative for malignancy. The examination was necessary to rule out a small metastatic focus.
This is ROI 3. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see mature adipose tissue (large white circles) and several small blood vessels. The central focus of interest is a small vessel, likely a lymphatic or venule, which contains a distinct cluster of malignant epithelial cells. These cells have large, dark (hyperchromatic), and irregular nuclei, forming a small, disorganized glandular structure. There is a mild lymphocytic infiltrate surrounding this vessel. My impression is that this is a clear example of lymphovascular invasion (LVI), where tumor cells are present within a vascular channel. This is a significant adverse prognostic finding.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I can clearly distinguish two different cell populations. The majority of the field consists of small, dark, round lymphocytes, which are the normal inhabitants of a lymph node. However, in the lower-right portion, there is a distinct, cohesive cluster of larger, atypical epithelial cells. These cells have more abundant pink (eosinophilic) cytoplasm and larger, more irregular, and paler (vesicular) nuclei compared to the surrounding lymphocytes. They appear to be forming ill-defined nests or glandular structures. This finding is diagnostic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, my impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing a metastatic deposit from the primary colorectal cancer.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a portion of a lymph node on the left and perinodal adipose tissue on the right. The lymph node tissue is composed of a dense population of small, round, dark-staining lymphocytes, which is consistent with normal or reactive lymphoid tissue. I do not see any definite clusters of malignant cells, atypical glands, or large pleomorphic cells that would suggest metastasis in this specific field. The capsule separating the lymph node from the fat appears intact. My impression of this particular area is that it is a benign/reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy. I would continue to scan the entirety of this node and all other nodes to confirm the absence of metastasis.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, the image clearly shows an interface between two distinct cell populations. On the left, there is a dense sheet of small, dark lymphocytes, which represents the residual, compressed normal lymph node tissue. On the right, there are infiltrative nests and irregular glands composed of large, atypical epithelial cells with pleomorphic, hyperchromatic nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm. This morphology is characteristic of adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic adenocarcinoma, confirming nodal metastasis from the primary colorectal cancer.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see a portion of a lymph node. Most of the field is composed of a dense sheet of small, dark-staining lymphocytes, which is the native cell population of the lymph node. However, there is a distinct, well-circumscribed, cohesive nodule of different cells. These cells are larger, with more abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, vesicular nuclei, and are arranged in a back-to-back glandular or cribriform pattern. This is a classic appearance of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is definitive: this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 8 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a lymph node surrounded by adipose tissue. The normal lymphoid architecture is partially effaced by infiltrative nests and glandular structures composed of atypical cells. These cells have large, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. The tumor cells are predominantly located in the subcapsular and cortical regions. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic adenocarcinoma.
